title: Synthetic Recap
body:
VANCOUVER — In the annals of the NBA, some victories are simply orchestrated by one man. On a night when the final score read Dallas 100, Vancouver 95, the real story was a singular, historic performance from a player who refused to let his team lose.

Michael Finley didn’t just play; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 42 points against the beleaguered Grizzlies. From the opening tip, Finley was a man possessed, slicing through the lane and launching from the perimeter with equal ferocity. Vancouver had no answer. His 42 points were not just a number; they were a relentless, 48-minute assault on every defensive scheme thrown his way.

While Finley’s scoring was otherworldly, he was not a one-man band. Jason Kidd, the maestro of the offense, conducted the show with a sublime 18-assist, 13-rebound double-double, feeding Finley in rhythm and controlling the game's tempo. A.C. Green provided the muscle inside, cleaning the glass with a game-high 16 rebounds to secure every miss.

The Grizzlies, led by Blue Edwards' 24 points and a strong 19-point, 10-rebound effort from Bryant Reeves, fought valiantly. They hung within striking distance, but every time they threatened, Finley had a response—a cold-blooded jumper, a powerful drive, a play that silenced the crowd.

In the end, this was not merely a road win for the Mavericks. It was the night Michael Finley etched his name into the record books and carried his team on his back. He delivered a performance for the ages, a dazzling 42-point declaration that in Dallas, a new star had truly arrived.
